title: Internal energy of ideal monatomic gas compressed

content.question:
An ideal monatomic gas is compressed while its temperature is held
 constant. What happens to the internal energy of the gas during this
 process, and why?

choices.label: It decreases because the gas does work on its surroundings.
It decreases because the molecules of an ideal gas collide.

It does not change because the internal energy of an ideal gas
 depends only on its temperature.
It increases because work is done on the gas.

It increases because the molecules travel a shorter path between
 collisions.

content.answer:
It does not change because the internal energy of an ideal gas
 depends only on its temperature.
